newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: KL overnight interbank rate steady at 10 pct.
newsitem.headline: KL overnight interbank rate steady at 10 pct.

text.p: The overnight interbank rate was steady at 10 percent on Monday after trading as high as 15 percent, dealers said.
They said a few banks, which are also agent banks of Bank Negara, were seen lending overnight money at 9/10 percent.
"We cannot tell if they are lending for Negara," said a dealer with Malaysian bank.
Earlier, a large agent bank of Bank Negara was also seen lending on the one-month.
The one-month rate was at 15/17 percent, against 15/20 percent on Friday.
One-week money was at 27 percent, against 25 percent.
Dealers said activities in the money market were mainly centred on the one-week and one-month. "Nobody dares to take beyond one-month because it is too expensive," one dealer said.
Dealers said the market remained short of ringgit funds following Bank Negara's buying of the currency last week to defend the ringgit from a speculative attack.
Although the actual size of the intervention was not known, dealers estimated that between 2.5 billion and 5.0 billion ringgit went out of the system.
Dealers said there was confusion over where rates are heading after Bank Negara appeared to be allowing the ringgit to weaken against the dollar on Monday.
The ringgit plunged to a 16-month low of 2.55 a dollar early on Monday, from 2.5042/52 at the end of Kuala Lumpur trading on Friday, as speculators sold down the Malaysian unit.
Around 0800 GMT, ringgit was at 2.5435/45 to a dollar.
Interest rate futures on the Malaysia Monetary Exchange fell to reflect future expectations of firmer rates.
At 0800 GMT, the three-month Kuala Lumpur Interbank Offered Rate (KLIBOR) September contract was down four points to 92.26, or an implied yield of 7.74 percent.
The December contract fell two to 92.53, or 7.47 percent.
